--- title: An Antarctic Tour of the Tidyverse subtitle: Quarto RevealJS Remix author: Silvia Canel√≥n, PhD format: revealjs: self-contained: false theme: ["default", "css/rladies-spc.scss"] history: false code-overflow: wrap df-print: default execute: echo: true title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: "images/lter_penguins.png" data-background-size: "35%" data-background-position: "50% 15%" data-background-color: "#562457" --- ## Setup {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell} ::: ## Silvia Canel√≥n {.center .center-x .nostretch background-image="https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1505168125601-4ddfdea4c7e7?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&auto=format&fit=crop&w=2102&q=80" background-size="cover"} Postdoctoral Research Scientist University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA [``{=html} silviacanelon.com](https://www.silviacanelon.com)
[``{=html} @spcanelon](https://twitter.com/spcanelon)
[``{=html} @spcanelon](https://github.com/spcanelon) ::: footer Photo by [Lucas Huffman](https://unsplash.com/@lukehuff?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText) on [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/s/photos/antarctica?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText) ::: ## Acknowledgments {.center} - Slides adapted from xaringan slides created for an [R-Ladies Chicago tutorial](https://github.com/spcanelon/tour-of-the-tidyverse) - Slides made using the [Quarto revealjs format](https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs/) - [palmerpenguins](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/intro.html) üì¶ developed by Drs. [Allison Horst](https://www.allisonhorst.com/), [Alison Hill](https://alison.rbind.io/), and [Kristen Gorman](https://www.uaf.edu/cfos/people/faculty/detail/kristen-gorman.php). - Penguin artwork by Allison Horst ([@allison_horst](https://twitter.com/allison_horst)) - Photographs from various photographers on Unsplash, and noted on the relevant slide ## Meet our penguin friends! :::: {.columns .center-x} ::: {.column width="30%"} ### Chinstrap ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ### Gentoo ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ### Ad√©lie ::: :::: ::: footer üêßPhotos by Long Ma on Unsplash ::: --- ## Collection of R packages, including
these 8 core packages (and more!) {.right background-image="images/pptx/tidyverse.png" background-size="80%"} # 01-readr {visibility="hidden"} ## {background-image="https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1591792111137-5b8219d5fad6?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&auto=format&fit=crop&w=4350&q=80" background-position="52% 5%" background-size="cover"} ![](images/pptx/01-readr.png){.absolute top=30 left=30 width="100%"} ::: footer Photo by James Eades on Unsplash ::: --- ## readr: info ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Overview :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Importing data is the very first step! ### You can use `readr` to import rectangular data. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### You can import... - comma separated (CSV) files with `read_csv()` - tab separated files with `read_tsv()` - general delimited files with `read_delim()` - fixed width files with `read_fwf()` - tabular files where columns are separated by white-space with `read_table()` - web log files with `read_log()` ::: :::: ### Cheatsheet {{< fa file-pdf >}} PDF: ![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/master/pngs/thumbnails/data-import-cheatsheet-thumbs.png) ### Reading :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} ![](images/r4ds-cover.png){width="300"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"}
### R for Data Science: [Ch 11 Data import](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-import.html) ### Package documentation: ::: :::: ::: ## readr: exercise ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Read data in #### Both options below will get you the same dataset,
try it out! {.center-x} Option 1: load using URL ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} read_csv("https://portal.edirepository.org/nis/dataviewer?packageid=knb-lter-pal.219.3&entityid=002f3893385f710df69eeebe893144ff") ``` :::
Option 2: load using filepath ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} read_csv("tutorial/raw_adelie.csv") ``` ::: ### Save data :::: {.columns} Lucky for us, the `palmerpenguins` üì¶ compiles data from all three species together for us! ::: {.column width="48%"} `penguins` contains a clean dataset ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins head(penguins) ## # A tibble: 6 √ó 8 ## species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_l‚Ä¶¬π body_‚Ä¶¬≤ sex year ## ## 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 male 2007 ## 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 fema‚Ä¶ 2007 ## 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 fema‚Ä¶ 2007 ## 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 2007 ## 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 fema‚Ä¶ 2007 ## 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 male 2007 ## # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãflipper_length_mm, ¬≤‚Äãbody_mass_g ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="48%"} `penguins_raw` contains raw data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins_raw <- palmerpenguins::penguins_raw head(penguins_raw) ## # A tibble: 6 √ó 17 ## study‚Ä¶¬π Sampl‚Ä¶¬≤ Species Region Island Stage Indiv‚Ä¶¬≥ Clutc‚Ä¶‚Å¥ `Date Egg` Culme‚Ä¶‚Åµ ## ## 1 PAL0708 1 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A1 Yes 2007-11-11 39.1 ## 2 PAL0708 2 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A2 Yes 2007-11-11 39.5 ## 3 PAL0708 3 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A1 Yes 2007-11-16 40.3 ## 4 PAL0708 4 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A2 Yes 2007-11-16 NA ## 5 PAL0708 5 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A1 Yes 2007-11-16 36.7 ## 6 PAL0708 6 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A2 Yes 2007-11-16 39.3 ## # ‚Ä¶ with 7 more variables: `Culmen Depth (mm)` , ## # `Flipper Length (mm)` , `Body Mass (g)` , Sex , ## # `Delta 15 N (o/oo)` , `Delta 13 C (o/oo)` , Comments , and ## # abbreviated variable names ¬π‚ÄãstudyName, ¬≤‚Äã`Sample Number`, ¬≥‚Äã`Individual ID`, ## # ‚Å¥‚Äã`Clutch Completion`, ‚Åµ‚Äã`Culmen Length (mm)` ``` ::: ::: :::: ::: # 02-tibble {visibility="hidden"} ## {background-image="https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1591792111137-5b8219d5fad6?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&auto=format&fit=crop&w=4350&q=80" background-position="52% 5%" background-size="cover"} ![](images/pptx/02-tibble.png){.absolute top=30 left=30 width="100%"} ::: footer Photo by James Eades on Unsplash ::: --- ## tibble: info ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Overview {.center} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"}

### A `tibble` is much like the `dataframe` in base R, but optimized for use in the Tidyverse.{.center} ::: :::: ### Cheatsheet {{< fa file-pdf >}} PDF: ![](images/cheatsheet/02-tibble-tidyr.png){width=65%} ### Reading :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} ![](images/r4ds-cover.png){width="300"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"}
### R for Data Science: [Ch 10 Tibbles](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/tibbles.html) ### Package documentation: ::: :::: ::: ## tibble: exercise ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code #### Let's take a look at the differences! {.center-x} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # try each of these commands in the console and see if # you can spot the differences! as_tibble(penguins) as.data.frame(penguins) ``` ::: ### Result ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as_tibble(penguins) |> head(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 8 species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_l‚Ä¶¬π body_‚Ä¶¬≤ sex year 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 male 2007 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 fema‚Ä¶ 2007 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 fema‚Ä¶ 2007 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 2007 # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãflipper_length_mm, ¬≤‚Äãbody_mass_g ``` ::: :::
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as.data.frame(penguins) |> head(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18.0 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA sex year 1 male 2007 2 female 2007 3 female 2007 4 2007 ``` ::: ::: ### Chat #### What differences do you see? You might see a `tibble` prints: - variable classes - only 10 rows - only as many columns as can fit on the screen - `NA`s are highlighted in console so they're easy to spot (font highlighting and styling in `tibble`) Not so much a concern in an R Markdown file, but noticeable in the console. Print method makes it easier to work with large datasets. ### More There are a couple of other main differences, namely in **subsetting** and **recycling**. Check them out in [`vignette("tibble")`](https://tibble.tidyverse.org/articles/tibble.html) #### Try it out! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vignette("tibble") ``` ::: ::: # 03-ggplot2 {visibility="hidden"} ## {background-image="https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1591792111137-5b8219d5fad6?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&auto=format&fit=crop&w=4350&q=80" background-position="52% 5%" background-size="cover"} ![](images/pptx/03-ggplot2.png){.absolute top=30 left=30 width="100%"} ::: footer Photo by James Eades on Unsplash ::: --- ## ggplot2: info ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Overview {.center}

#### Let's start by making a simple plot of our data! #### `ggplot2` uses the "Grammar of Graphics" and layers graphical components together to create a plot. ### Cheatsheet {{< fa file-pdf >}} PDF: ![](images/cheatsheet/03-ggplot2.png){width=100%} ### Reading :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} ![](images/r4ds-cover.png){width="300"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"}
### R for Data Science: [Ch 3 Data visualization](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html) ### Package documentation: ::: :::: ::: ## ggplot2: exercise ::: {.panel-tabset} ### View the data Get a full view of the dataset: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} View(penguins) ``` :::
Or catch a `glimpse`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 344 Columns: 8 $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel‚Ä¶ $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse‚Ä¶ $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, ‚Ä¶ $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, ‚Ä¶ $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186‚Ä¶ $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, ‚Ä¶ $ sex male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male‚Ä¶ $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ### Scatterplot Let's see if body mass varies by penguin sex using `geom_point()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ### Boxplot Let's see if body mass varies by penguin sex, this time with `geom_boxplot()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ### By Species Let's see if body mass varies by penguin sex, and now fill the boxplots
according to penguin species ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot(aes(fill = species)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/by-species-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: #### What do you notice? {.right} ### Chat #### You might see... - Gentoo penguins have higher body mass than Ad√©lie and Chinstrap penguins - Higher body mass among male Gentoo penguins compared to female penguins - Pattern not as discernible when comparing Ad√©lie and Chinstrap penguins - No `NA`s among Chinstrap penguin data points! **sex** was available for each observation ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
